title: Uncommon download alert vs signed application - will EV change anything?
content:
Hi,

from time to time I'm facing the issue which is reported to me by my clients, that signing the application (for example .exe files) with commercial code signing certificate does not help them to get rid of "Uncommon download" notification when their application is downloaded.

I'm trying (and I hope that someone will help me to answer to this question) to figure out if signing the application with EV code signing certificate should help in this case? Personally often I can't even prove that the problem with specific file exists, because when I download the example file, I'm not notified about uncommon download, but screenshots from my clients are real.

Of course I've read any document I found describing how the Google Safe Browsing mechanism works and I do understand that it is developed to protect the users, but my question about EV certificate is still wondering me.

Microsoft advisor described that EV signing may help for Edge users: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/886010/avoiding-microsoft-edge-isnt-commonly-downloaded-w. What about Firefox?

I'm ready to provide some examples if needed but the question seems global to me.

Best regards, Paula
creator: polszowka

title: Disable Updates - PERMANENTLY - On Firefox!
content:
How to PERMANENTLY disable updates on all versions of Firefox from the latest backward.

Don't try and re-school us on allowing auto updates. Please allow us the choice. There are many people with many legitimate reasons for wanting and needing to turn this off and have it stay turned off. Those of us using various retro versions of Firefox also need this option. No further explanations needed!

Lets start with putting the choice to Never Update back in the options.

Worse yet, this program re-writes registry keys and options settings when the computer and/or program is restarted, so that the update options are changed back to the default auto install. This is causing problems on internal networks to the point of making the browser unusable.

What about time lost in having to turn this off each time the computer is restarted. For instance, if you are using a laptop in a limited data situation. You have turned this off previously. You shut the machine down for the night. In the morning you need to connect and do work and turn the machine on while you walk away for a minute because it's set to do mail and make connections to work network automatically. When you return, its stuck because auto updates are running. The internal work network connection times out and that system is locked up. So now you have to call IT. Morning lost.

As private users, not being able to turn this off permanently is making us stop using Firefox altogether. We want sovereignty over OUR computers. We paid for them and feel we can throw them out the window if we want! (I've done this many times.) Remember the customer being "right"!

Repeat after me. WE OWN OUR COMPUTERS! We are the final word on them! You need to understand that.

How about just a succinct answer on how to do this. "Anything less is uncivilized."
creator: info8810

title: How do I change where Firefox stores Cookies?
content:
I recently switched over to using an SSD, and I am trying to do everything I can to prevent unnecessary writing to that drive. I've already found instructions for moving the location of Firefox's Cache files to my secondary HDD, but I haven't been able to do the same for Cookies; they're still being stored on my C: drive, in the AppData folder.

Is it possible to change the path that Firefox uses to store Cookies? If it is possible, how?

title: Address bar & Google desktop search suggestions
content:
Somehow I lost the Google suggestions that are displayed in the center of the page as shown in the image. Those suggestions have not displayed for several days.

Initially I thought they disappeared when updating Firefox but now I'm not sure. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1406299

However I noticed what looked like "90%" displayed in the address bar somewhere within the red circle. I clicked on it in order to see what it was about & the "90%" disappeared & the Google suggestions reappeared.

I've been searching to find out what the heck I clicked on that restored the Google suggestions. Everything is now working like it used to, but I'm curious about what I clicked up that controlled the suggestions. Anyone have any idea?

Thanks

title: Firefox ESR 102.80 issues with Sharepoint and OneDrive
content:
When trying to open Sharepoint or OneDrive Sites I receive either an 401 Access denied or a: We are sorry, something went wrong.

The issue is actually described in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1373433 It seems that it broke again now. There are also other people having this problem: https://www.reddit.com/r/sysadmin/comments/11aot6r/firefox_10280esr_seems_to_have_broken/


If I either clear all cache, active logins and cookies or reload with STRG + F5 it will work temporarily. Setting dom.serviceWorkers.navigationPreload.enabled to False fixes it completely.

title: Email bounce detection issue when creating new account
content:
I’m trying to create a new Firefox Sync for a family member and the email they are using for it is a business email. When trying to sign up Firefox said the email was bounced and to check the address. We know the address is right because we received the email code. My guess is that Firefox mistakes the auto reply email with a bounce back. As I said this is a commercial account so they have an auto reply setup (“Thanks for reaching out, we will get back to you etc”). Now I’m waiting for 15’ before I can try to sign in again because it locked me out. I understand the feature is supposed to be helpful but if you can’t reliably detect real bounce backs it should be disabled. If I can’t use this address to create the account because of this my options are: - Tell this person to create a new email - Ask them to disable the auto reply in their current email - Don’t use Sync at all

None of these options is desirable or practical.
creator: diegus831
